p: NO 2 concentrations are particularly high in cities near major transport corridors where socio-economically deprived and poor people and ethnic minorities are over-represented [ 26, 27]. If PM concentrations have similar distribution patterns then their increase in changing climate would increase the exposure of the same people to the adverse health outcomes of PM. The situation with O 3 is more complex as high urban NO and N0 2 concentrations inhibit the formation of O 3. However, high O 3 concentrations can prevail in cities in future if public policies do succeed in bringing down urban nitrogen oxide emissions [ 28].
